Yadav * Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, Mumbai, 400 019, India Department of Chemical Engineering Institute of Chemical Technology Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga Mumbai 400 019 India Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, Mumbai-400 019, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cyclohexanone is the key ingredient for the manufacture of ε-caprolactam which is used for making Nylon 6. In this work, non-oxidative vapor phase dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone was carried out over monovalent copper using CuZnMg catalyst. The catalyst was prepared by co-precipitation method and characterized using different techniques, viz. XRD, FTIR, TPD, TPR, TGA, BET, SEM, EDX, and XPS. Cyclohexanol conversion of 55.0 % was resulted with 99.2 % selectivity of cyclohexanone at 260 ℃ with WHSV of 2.34 h−1. Time on stream study (125 h) and catalyst reusability studies were performed to find that the catalyst was robust, stable and easily reusable. A reaction mechanism over surface Cu+ is discussed and kinetics deduced. Keywords Cyclohexanone Non-oxidative dehydrogenation Copper catalyst Fixed bed reactor Cyclohexanol 1 Introduction ε-Caprolactam has a huge demand for its use to make Nylon 6 filaments, fibres, and plastics. It has also been used in the synthesis of several pharmaceutical drugs including pentylenetetrazol, meptazinol, and laurocapram. Cyclohexanone is the basic raw material in the synthesis of ε-caprolactam. ε-Caprolactam must be very pure because the impurities coming from its raw materials, affect the polymerization process during synthesis of Nylon 6 [1]. Catalytic dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone is an important process well reported to synthesize high purity cyclohexanone. In recent studies low temperature copper oxide catalysed nonoxidative dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol has been studied in order to improve both conversion and cyclohexanone selectivity [2–4]. The reaction being endothermic (ΔH =65 kJ/mol), increase in temperature improves the conversion of cyclohexanol but on the other hand copper catalyst being thermally unstable, sintering of catalyst has always been a drawback of the process. Different supports and different combinations of mixed metal oxides containing copper oxide as catalysts are reported to overcome the shortcomings of the process include Cu/alumina [2,3], Cu/carbon covered alumina [2], Cu/ZnO-Al2O3 [4–6], Ru-Cu/alumina [7], Cu/MgO [5,8], Cu/ZnO [5], commercial catalysts such as Cu-1230 (72 % CuO, 26 % CuCr2O4) and Cu-0203 (33 % CuO, 66 % ZnO and 1% graphite) [9], Cu-MgO-Cr2O3 [10], Cu-ZnO-Cr2O3 [11], Cu/SiO2 [12,13], Cu-ZnO/SiO2 [14], Cu-Fe/SiO2 [15], and Cu-Mn/SiO2 [16]. According to the literature, there are two different mechanisms for this conversion over different active sites of copper in oxidation states Cu+1 and Cu0. Cyclohexanol dehydrogenation over monovalent copper proceeds via non-dissociative adsorption of cyclohexanol with subsequent formation of cyclohexanol alcoholate of Cu+. The highly reactive adsorbed cyclohexanol oxide is then rapidly converted into cyclohexanone without any by-products. On the contrary, cyclohexanol adsorption on Cu0 sites is dissociative which proceeds via rupture of the OH bond and formation of two different adsorbed species: cyclohexanol alcoholate and phenolate. These species are the intermediates for the formation cyclohexanone and phenol, respectively. Due to formation of two kinds of adsorbed intermediates simultaneously, the selectivity of cyclohexanone is less for cyclohexanol dehydrogenation over Cu0 [5]. Table 1 gives detailed knowledge about the various efficient catalysts used for non-oxidative dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol, their effect on conversion and selectivity of cyclohexanone and the responsible active site. It is evident that ZnO doped catalyst tend to follow non-dissociative reaction mechanism with Cu+ as main surface active species and it can avoid aromatization of cyclohexanol to form phenol [6]. Thus, ZnO loading is an important factor to balance the Cu+/Cu0 ratio as it affects the reducibility of CuO [17]. On the other hand, in copper catalysts supported on MgO, are reported to have Cu0 as surface active species [6,8,18]. Mixed metal oxides are acid–base bifunctional catalysts [19]. In cyclohexanol dehydrogenation, the acidic sites in the catalyst also leads to the formation of cyclohexene as result of dehydration occurring parallelly with dehydrogenation. Thus, Cu catalysts containing Al2O3, Cr2O3 and SiO2 resulted in lesser selectivity due to the presence of cyclohexene in product stream [2,3,11,14]. MgO, an alkaline earth metal oxide, acts as a solid base catalyst and balances the acid-base characteristic of the catalyst. It also acts better as a support towards dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol, avoiding dehydration reaction [20]. Nagaraja et al. have studied effect of different synthetic methods of Cu/MgO on dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol [8]. The catalyst prepared by co-precipitation after reduction had Cu0 as active species with 64.3 % conversion and 100 % selectivity at 250 ℃. The conversion reduced drastically as the temperature increased further at 280 ℃ and 300 ℃. This can be attributed to sintering of metallic copper beyond 250℃, causing deactivation of the catalyst. It is thus important to improve the thermal stability of catalyst. Stable metal oxides of Al, Si, Zn, Cr, Fe, Ni, alkali metals, and alkaline earth metals are added to the copper catalysts to enhance their properties [21]. In the current study, we have used CuO-ZnO-MgO mixed metal oxide catalyst for selective synthesis of cyclohexanone from cyclohexanol. The addition of ZnO was very useful because it promoted the dispersion and thermal stability of the resulting copper catalysts [2,21]. A long-time on-stream study made the catalyst attractive towards industrial use. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Copper (II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2•3H2O.), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2•6H2O), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2•6H2O), cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3•6H2O), and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and all other precursors were purchased from Thomas Baker Chemicals, India. Cyclohexanol was procured from Sigma Aldrich, India. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The catalysts were synthesised by co-precipitation method. CuO-ZnO-MgO was prepared as follows: Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (7.36 g) was dissolved in 100 mL of water to get 0.5 M solution (Solution A). Copper (II) nitrate trihydrate (6 g) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (4.65 g) were dissolved in 100 mL of water (Solution B). Solution B and 0.1 M NaOH were added dropwise to solution A with continuous stirring of 800 rpm. After completing addition of solution B, the pH was monitored regularly. NaOH addition was continued until the pH of the mixture was 10−12. The precipitates formed were filtered and washed thoroughly using DI water to make the pH 7. The solid mass thus obtained was dried at 100℃ for 12 h. Afterwards it was calcined at 500℃ for 5 h. CuO-ZnO-MgO (1:1:1) is denoted as CuZnMg (1:1:1) henceforth. Similarly other mixed metal oxides were also synthesized by co-precipitation method and denoted as CuZnAl (2:2:1), MoZnMg (1:1:1), CuZnHMS (1:1:1), CuCe(1:1), CuZnMg (1.5:1:1), and CuMg (1:1). The ratios provided in the parentheses denote the ratio of each metal by weight in their oxide form. 2.3 Dehydrogenation of cyclohexanone and product analysis The non-oxidative dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol was performed in a down flow vapor phase reactor (fixed bed reactor). The details of the reactor parameters are provided in supporting information (SI). The effects of different reaction parameters such as catalyst loading, WHSV, and temperature, etc. on the conversion of cyclohexanol and selectivity of cyclohexanone were studied. The used catalyst was regenerated by calcining it again 500℃ for 5 h. Catalyst reusability and time on stream (TOS) studies were also carried out. The conversion of cyclohexanol as well as selectivity of cyclohexanone were quantified using Thermo 1110 gas chromatography model (TG5MS capillary column with dimensions as 0.25 mm ×30 m). The identification of products and by-products was done using Thermo Scientific ISQLT 1300 GCMS model (capillary column TG5MS; 0.25 mm ×30 m). Mass spectra of cyclohexanone is provided in SI (Fig. S1). 2.4 Catalyst characterization and product analysis The catalysts were characterized using different techniques; namely, temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy Dispersive X-Ray Analysis (EDX), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The characterization of catalyst at different stages helped to understand the adsorption-desorption mechanism of reaction over the heterogeneous catalysts used. The detailed specifications of these instruments are provided in SI. information. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 TPD Acidic and basic properties of the catalysts were initially investigated using both NH3 and CO2 TPD, respectively (Table 2 ). It was desirable for the catalyst to have optimum acidity as well as basicity to result in the highest possible cyclohexanol conversion with best possible cyclohexanone selectivity. The catalysts CuZnAl, CuZnHMS, and MoZnMg have high acidity values which may result in dehydration as side reaction. CuMg, CuCe, and CuZnMg have good basicity values which may result in highly selective cyclohexanone product. The conversions and selectivity using the following catalysts are discussed in catalyst screening section. 3.1.2 XRD The crystallite phase analysis of catalyst surfaces was performed using powder XRD. XRD studies reveal a high degree of purity and crystallinity of nanoparticles. The diffraction patterns of fresh CuMg, CuZnMg, spent CuZnMg (after 125 h) as well as regenerated CuZnMg were recorded and compared with CuO and ZnO patterns (Fig. 1 ). CuO and ZnO had monoclinic (JCPDS card No. 80-1917) and hexagonal wurtzite structures (JCPDS card, No. 65-3411), respectively. The XRD pattern of CuMg showed the presence of monoclinic CuO on the surface where as CuZnMg had both CuO and ZnO on the surface. The intensities of CuO peaks decrease due to the presence of ZnO. Crystallite sizes of both the materials were estimated by Debye–Scherrer equation from the XRD patterns. CuMg and CuZnMg were found to have 17.86 nm and 19.28 nm crystallite sizes, respectively. In spent catalysts after 125 h time on stream study, some extra peaks were observed with reduced crystallinity. The extra peaks might be due to reduction of CuO to Cu2O, as H2 is continuously produced in the dehydrogenation reaction. Gas chromatogram of H2 gas produced by TCD detector is shown in Fig. S2. Catalyst when regenerated by calcining again, was seen to regain its crystallinity and previous oxidation state. 3.1.3 FTIR IR spectra of CuO, ZnO, CuZnMg and recovered CuZnMg are shown in Fig. 2 . The broad absorption peaks within 400−600 cm−1 represent the metal-oxygen bonds. The IR spectra of CuO exhibit only three vibrations at approximately 482 cm−1, 536 cm−1, and 576 cm−1 of Cu-O, conﬁrming the formation of highly pure CuO nanoparticles. ZnO has broad peak at 468 cm−1 whereas in CuZnMg the ZnO maximum is split in to two maxima, one at 590 and the second one at 528 cm−1. The shift in these ZnO absorption bands is attributed to the incorporation of ZnO into CuO. Peaks in the range of 1400−1600 cm−1 in the spectra indicate the presence of metal carbonyl groups at the surface of resultant material. The regenerated catalyst also has very similar spectrum to that of fresh catalyst. 3.1.4 BET surface area Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of CuZnMg and recovered CuZnMg were calculated using N2 adsorption- desorption method (Fig. 3 ). Type IV isotherm obtained conformed mesoporous structure of the catalysts. The surface area of CuZnMg catalyst was 34.36 m2/g with a pore volume of 0.29 cm3/g and pore size of 33.7 nm. Regenerated CuZnMg had surface area of 33.58 and pore volume of 0.28 cm3/g with 32.9 nm pore size. Whereas CuMg exhibited a BET surface area of 12.30 m2/g, pore volume of 0.087 cm3/g, and pore size of 15.9 nm. It can be seen that incorporation of ZnO improves the surface area as well as pore volume of the catalyst [23]. 3.1.5 TGA analysis Thermal stability of fresh CuZnMg catalyst, spent CuZnMg after 125 h and regenerated CuZnMg was analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 4 ). Fresh and regenerated catalysts were calcined at 500 ℃ before TGA analysis. Very negligible weight loss was observed in both fresh and regenerated catalysts. Spent catalyst was unstable and the weight was gradually reduced to 97.8 %. The weight loss can be attributed to evaporation and oxidation of adsorbed carbonaceous material over the catalyst. Overall the catalyst was found to be stable up to 500 °C. 3.1.6 TPR analysis TPR studies of the co-precipitated CuZnMg catalyst were performed using 10 % H2-Ar. The temperature ramp was kept constant 20℃/min from 50℃ to 600℃. TPR studies reveal the metal- metal interactions and the reducibility of catalyst. Reduction of the catalyst CuZnMg was visible by a sharp intense peak at 228℃, very small shoulder peak 297℃ and a broad asymmetric peak with maxima at 502℃ and 557℃ (Fig. 5 ). The intense peak is attributed to reduction of CuO and broad peak at high temperatures may be due to reduction of Cu2O or partial reduction of ZnO and MgO phases. As H2 is the coproduct in cyclohexanol dehydrogenation reaction, in the temperature range of 150℃-280℃, CuO is reduced creating more active sites for the reaction whereas ZnO and MgO do not get reduced under experimental conditions of cyclohexanol dehydrogenation. The hydrogen consumption of this low temperature process is thus dependant on CuO percentage in the catalyst. However, there is no evidence of a stepwise reduction of Cu+2 to Cu+ and Cu+ to Cu0 as was observed in the reduction of CuO-ZnO as studied by Fierro et al. [17]. 3.1.7 SEM and EDX analysis Surface morphology of CuZnMg was studied by SEM analysis and elemental composition was confirmed using EDX. Fig. 6 shows the spherical particles of mixed metal oxides with average particle sizes of 120−150 nm. The particle size was also confirmed by HRTEM analysis. All three metal oxides can be seen uniformly distributed which can be also confirmed by EDX analysis of the catalyst. As EDX is done in a single area of catalyst, the results cannot be said to be uniform in all areas of catalyst. Figs. 7 and S3 represent the EDX data at three different points. As per the addition of metal precursors all the metal oxides should be present in equal amounts (in % by weight). EDX analysis calculated the average mass percentages of CuO, ZnO and MgO, as 29.86, 39.48, and 30.63 respectively. The data roughly matches with the expected mass percentages values. 3.1.8 TEM analysis HRTEM analysis of CuZnMg catalyst was performed to understand the distribution of different metal oxides. Fig. 8 shows that smaller CuO and ZnO particles up to 10−30 nm are adsorbed over bigger particles of MgO in the range of 100−120 nm.The lattice fridges of CuO and ZnO are seen proving the crystallinity as shown in XRD images above. 3.1.9 XPS analysis XPS analysis of fresh CuZnMg and spent CuZnMg after 125 h was performed to find out the elemental composition and changes in the oxidation state of the copper after cyclohexanol dehydrogenation. In the wide spectra for fresh catalyst, the binding energy peaks at 1042 eV and 1019 eV were due to Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2, respectively. The peak at 1303.23 eV can be attributed to Mg 1 s of magnesium oxide (Fig. S1). Copper (Cu2+) had two binding energy peaks at 933 and 953.93 eV with strong Cu+2 satellite peaks at 942.13 and 961.50 eV, which confirms the presence of Cu2+ (Fig. 9 ). It is possible to distinguish Cu oxidation states using satellite features of Cu2p, as Cu (I) oxide; there is only a very weak satellite around 945 eV. Fig. 8 shows high resolution spectra of copper from fresh CuZnMg as well as spent catalyst. The shifts in the peaks towards lower binding energy values and less intensities of satellite peaks of Cu2+ in spent catalyst may be due to the reduction of Cu2+. As Cu metal and Cu+ has the same binding energies it is difficult to state the final oxidation states of copper after reduction. 3.2 Dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol 3.2.1 Catalyst screening A wide range of metal oxides in combination with CuO were studied for dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone such as CuZnAl (2:2:1), MoZnMg (1:1:1), CuZnHMS (1:1:1), CuCe(1:1), CuZnMg (1:1:1), and CuMg (1:1). To study the synergistic effect of temperature and metal oxide combinations, the reactions were performed at both 240 and 260℃ with 1 g catalyst loading and 2.34h−1 WHSV (Fig. 10 ). CuZnAl (2:2:1) catalyst is the most preferably studied catalyst for this conversion, which resulted in 70.98 % and 84.4 % conversions at 240 and 260℃, respectively, but had less selectivity of cyclohexanone in the range of 71–74 %. Similarly, the catalysts MoZnMg (1:1:1) and CuZnHMS (1:1:1) also lack in better selectivity of cyclohexanone, due to the presence of excess acidic sites which result in dehydration reaction to produce cyclohexene as by-product. CuCe (1:1) had very less conversions at both temperatures, the selectivity was 98.16 at 240℃ which reduced to 92.52 % at 260℃. CuMg resulted in conversions of 48.67 % and 62.8 % at 240 and 260℃, respectively which are better than 45.34 % and 54.97 % of CuZnMg. But as incorporation of zinc oxide improves the thermal and physical stability of the catalyst against sintering and deactivation, CuZnMg is considered as viable catalyst for dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol. Both the catalysts had very good selectivity for cyclohexanone. At 240℃ the selectivity was higher than 260℃. When concentration of ZnO in the catalyst was increased than CuO in catalyst CuZnMg (1:2:1) both the conversion of cyclohexanol as well as cyclohexanone selectivity was comparatively decreased. The activity loss was due to a smaller number of active sites present per g of catalyst and loss in cyclohexanone selectivity could due to other active sites present on ZnO which favoured the formation of side products such as cyclohexene. Thus, the catalyst CuZnMg (1:1:1) was considered as the suitable catalyst with good conversion and selectivity coupled with better stability. 3.2.2 Effect of catalyst loading The effect of catalyst amount mounted in the reactor, on conversion and selectivity in dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol was studied (Fig. 11 ). All reactions were performed using CuZnMg (1:1.5:1) catalyst at 260℃, with initial feed flow rate of 0.05 mL/min. With increase in the catalyst amount from 0.5 g to 2 g, the conversion increased from 24.8% to 71.8 % but the selectivity decreased from 100 % to 92.30 %. The increase in conversion can be attributed to increase in number of catalytic active sites as the amount of catalyst loaded is increased. But, due to increase in catalyst loading with the same feed flow rate, residence time of cyclohexanol on the catalyst surface increased, which resulted in decrease in selectivity of cyclohexanone. Side products such as di-cyclohexyl ether and cyclohexene were observed. Thus, catalyst loading of 1 g, which resulted in 54.97 % conversion and 99.2 % selectivity was considered as the optimum for further sets of reactions. 3.2.3 Effect of WHSV The effect of WHSV (1.40 h−1,1.87 h−1,2.34 h−1, and 2.81 h−1) on conversion of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone selectivity was studied by varying the flow rates of cyclohexanol from 0.03 to 0.06 mL/min (Fig. 12 ). All reactions were performed using CuZnMg (1:1.5:1) catalyst with 1 g of catalyst loading at 260℃. At WHSV of 1.4 h−1 the highest conversion of cyclohexanol was obtained but the selectivity of cyclohexanol was less. On other hand, with increase in WHSV, at 2.34 and 2.81 h−1, the selectivity of cyclohexanone was increased to around 99 % with cyclohexanol conversions of 55 % and 47.7 %, respectively. With increase in the flow rate, the WHSV increases which practically means the residence time of cyclohexanol molecule on the active sites of catalyst reduces. The less residence time is responsible to avoid reactions occurring in series to produce side products such as di-cyclohexyl ether and cyclohexene. Thus, WHSV of 2.34 with 55 % conversion and 99.2 % selectivity was considered as the optimum. 3.2.4 Effect of temperature The effect of temperature on cyclohexanol dehydrogenation was investigated by carrying out reactions at 200, 220, 240, 260, and 280℃. The temperature study revealed that rise in temperature increased the cyclohexanol conversion but it was not in favour of the selectivity of cyclohexanone (Fig. 13 ). The conversion was 26. 8 % at 200℃, which increased to 62.2 % at 280℃ and the selectivity was above 99 % up to 260℃, but it reduced when temperature was further increased to 280℃. This observation can be attributed to activation of different acidic sites at high temperature other than dominant active sites producing cyclohexanone. These acidic sites become responsible for the production of cyclohexene as by-product. Thus, temperature of 260℃ with good conversion as well as selectivity was considered as the optimum temperature to carry out this reaction. 3.2.5 Time on stream (TOS) study TOS study was performed to find out the stability of catalyst for dehydrogenation cyclohexanol. The reaction was carried out continuously for 125 h using CuZnMg catalyst with 1 g catalyst loading and 2.34 h−1 WHSV at 260℃. The catalyst was found to be very stable both thermally and structurally. The cyclohexanol conversions were found constant in the range of 51–55 %, the selectivity of cyclohexanone was <99 % even after 125 h (Fig. 14 ). The catalyst can thus be said as efficient for industrial usage. 3.2.6 Catalyst reusability study Although TOS study revealed that the catalyst activity was sustained even after 125 h and there was no need of regeneration of the catalyst for its reuse. However, over prolonged time it may be needed to recycle the catalyst and reused for next consecutive batches. Simon et al. observed the deactivation of commercial copper zinc oxide catalyst due to coking at 300℃. Thus, catalyst reusability studies were performed for 4 batches to understand the possibility of recovery and reuse of the spent catalyst (Fig. 15 ). For reactivation of the catalyst, the spent catalyst (after 10 h run) was flushed with nitrogen gas (100 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h. The dried catalyst thus obtained was washed with IPA to wash out the adsorbed cyclohexanol from the catalyst. Then, it was recalcined at 500 ℃ for 5 h. The loss in weight of catalyst occurred due to this regeneration process was calculated and made up with fresh catalyst to get the same catalyst loading. The catalyst could also be regenerated simply by calcining at 500℃ inside the reactor by passing air through the reactor. The catalyst reusability study was done up to 4th reuse as shown in Fig. 6. It was found that both cyclohexanol conversions as well as cyclohexanone selectivity were almost similar for the reused catalyst batches with marginal differences. 4 Reaction mechanism Cu+ and Cu0 both are considered as active sites for dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone. As per literature, monovalent copper is significantly active as well as selective than zero valent copper due to the formation of phenolate species over Cu0 during dehydrogenation [6]. There was no phenol produced as side product in our work and thus it can be inferred that for unreduced CuO catalyst, Cu0 or Cu+ are formed after some interval of dehydrogenation wherein H2 evolved in the reaction reduces the surface CuO. Zhan et al. also used unreduced CuO catalyst in order to determine whether Cu2+ ions are active for methanol dehydrogenation. It was found that conversion and the selectivity were not comparable with reduced catalysts until the catalysts were used for at least one hour, which is explained in terms of the reduction of Cu2+ by H2 coming out as a co-product of dehydrogenation. Thus, the reduced copper or probably Cu+ was considered to be the active species for methanol dehydrogenation [24]. Cu oxide in mixed metal oxide is known to have anionic vacancy defect which leads to the formation of Cu+/Cu2+ redox couple [25,26]. This typical redox couple is one of the important factors in improving the catalytic activity of dehydrogenation reactions. Scheme 1 shows a plausible reaction mechanism of dehydrogenation cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone. The first step involves adsorption of cyclohexanol over copper oxide and the interaction of hydroxyl group with lattice oxygen and Cu+ species. This interaction further leads in dissociative chemisorption of hydroxyl group of cyclohexanol onto the surface sites where the oxygen forms bond with monovalent copper site and hydrogen of hydroxyl group is abstracted as a proton by lattice oxygen. In the next step hydride transfer from cyclohexanol to Cu2+ species occurs to produce cyclohexanone as shown in Scheme 1. The last step involves desorption of Cu-O bond to form cyclohexanone and generation of free hydrogen. 5 Reaction kinetics Selective conversion of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone is a non-oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. It contains cyclohexanol (COH) as a reactant and cyclohexanone (CONE) as the product. Gaseous co-product hydrogen (G) is assumed not to get chemisorbed. According to mechanism of heterogeneously catalysed reactions, the first step is chemisorption of cyclohexanol on the vacant catalytic site (S) (6) C O H + S ↔ K A C O H S The chemisorbed cyclohexanol (COHS) undergoes dehydrogenation reaction giving adsorbed chemisorbed cyclohexanone as product (CONE) as follows (7) C O H S → k C O N E S + G The rate of cyclohexanol COH conversion (mol/h per g of catalyst) is given by: (8) - r C O H = k C C O H C S The concentration of vacant sites CS can be calculated from the concentration of total sites (Ct), adsorption equilibrium constants (Ki), and concentrations of relevant species (Ci) (9) C t = C s + C C O H S + C G S (10) C s = C t 1 + ∑ K i C i According to Eqs. (9) and (10), (8) becomes, (11) - r C O H = k K C O H C C O H 1 + ∑ K i C i Considering weak adsorption of all the species are and when ∑ K i C i ≪ 1 , the equation of rate of reaction can be written as (12) - r C O H = k K C O H C C O H (13) - r C O H = k ' C C O H (14) k ' = k K C O H Where k’ is the overall rate constant upon integrating Eq. (13), for a fixed bed vapor phase catalytic reactor we get, (15) - ln 1 - X C O H = k ' C C O H o W F C O H o Plot of −ln (1 – XCOH) vs W/FCOHo vs temperature was generated to calculate the rate constants at various reaction temperatures (Fig. 16 ) and the Arrhenius plot was also generated to calculate the apparent activation energy which is 6.83 kcal/mol (Fig. 17 ). This is a two-phase gas-solid (G-S) reaction system: the reactant cyclohexanol, product cyclohexanone and coproduct hydrogen as gas phase and the catalyst as porous solid phase. In this system, volumetric mass transfer coefficients solid-gas ( k S G S e x t ) need to be considered for finding relative rates of mass transfer and reaction for each species, where k S G and S e x t are true S-G mass transfer coefficient and particle surface area, respectively. The particle surface area ( S e x t ) which is equal to 6 W ρ p d p which is very high where W is catalyst loading (g), ρ p particle density and d p is the average particle diameter. For the transfer of gas phase reactant and products, G-S interface to the catalyst particle, k S G S e x t will matter. The values of k S G and S e x t , and hence the rates of mass transfer for each species were calculated using the following correlation for a fluid passing through a packed bed of particles: S h = k S G d p D G = 2 + 1.8 Re p 0.5 S c 0.33 f o r R e p > 80 The bulk diffusivity D G of cyclohexanol was estimated from Wlike-Change equation. The limiting value of Sherwood number (Sh) of 2 was taken because the Rep for average particle size of 0.2 μm was small. Rep particle Reynold’s number and Sc the Schmidt number. To verify whether S-G mass transfer resistance is important, the external surface of particle was used and the values of the observed rate constant k o b s were compared with k S G S e x t . It was found that k o b s < k S G S e x t , hence there was absence of mass transfer resistance. Further, a theoretical analysis was done to evaluate the intra-particle diffusion resistance through the Weisz-Prater criterion, C W P = R p 2 r o b s ρ p D e f f C A . Where, R p = particle radius, r o b s = observed rate, ρ p = bulk density of catalyst, D e f f = effective diffusivity of cyclohexanol, C A = concentration of cyclohexanol. At the actual superficial velocity of the vapour phase, the calculations were done for the actual loading (1 g) and the maximum temperature (260 °C) and WHSV of 0.34 h−1 to ascertain absence of intra-particle diffusion resistance. The effective diffusivity within the pore was calculated from bulk diffusivity and the average pore diameter. Thus, the value of C W P was found to be 0.087 which is much lower than 1 and hence the reaction is free from intra-particle diffusion resistance [27] Thus, the reaction was kinetically controlled. The reaction was found to be kinetically controlled with to have an apparent activation energy of 6.83 kcal/mol. 6 Conclusion Monovalent copper was found to be more selective for non-oxidative dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone than metallic copper in CuZnMg (1:1:1) mixed metal oxide. MgO provided the necessary basicity to the catalyst to avoid dehydration as side reaction and ZnO acted as the stability promoter for TOS of 125 h. Both of these properties make the catalyst industrially attractive. Maximum conversion of 55 % was obtained with 99.2 % cyclohexanone selectivity using CuZnMg (1:1:1) mixed metal oxide catalyst at 260℃ at WHSV of 2.34 h−1. The catalyst was found very stable up to 125 h with almost constant conversion and selectivity. After several uses the deactived catalyst could also be easily reactivated and reused. The reaction was found to have an apparent activation energy of 6.83 kcal/mol. CRediT authorship contribution statement This work was performed by Ms. Sonam V. coredata.dc:description: Cyclohexanone is the key ingredient for the manufacture of ε-caprolactam which is used for making Nylon 6. In this work, non-oxidative vapor phase dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone was carried out over monovalent copper using CuZnMg catalyst. The catalyst was prepared by co-precipitation method and characterized using different techniques, viz. XRD, FTIR, TPD, TPR, TGA, BET, SEM, EDX, and XPS. Cyclohexanol conversion of 55.0 % was resulted with 99.2 % selectivity of cyclohexanone at 260 ℃ with WHSV of 2.34 h−1. Time on stream study (125 h) and catalyst reusability studies were performed to find that the catalyst was robust, stable and easily reusable. A reaction mechanism over surface Cu+ is discussed and kinetics deduced.
coredata.dc:title: CuO-ZnO-MgO as sustainable and selective catalyst towards synthesis of cyclohexanone by dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol over monovalent copper
